title: Mapping the Invisible Stuff That Holds the Universe Together
summary: Scientists have made a new map of something called dark matter that we cannot see. Dark matter is a hidden part of the Universe that helps hold everything together. Using a big space telescope called James Webb, they found that dark matter pulls on normal matter, which is the stuff we can see like stars and planets. This pulling helped form galaxies like our Milky Way and planets like Earth long ago. The map shows how dark matter shaped the Universe we live in today. It is like an invisible architect that built the structures in space. Scientists from places like Durham University worked together on this study to learn more about how the Universe was made.

keywords.explanation: invisible stuff in space that we cannot see but helps hold the Universe together
a picture or chart that shows where things are, like a map of dark matter in space
a big telescope in space that scientists use to look at stars and galaxies
big groups of stars, like the Milky Way where we live
a force that pulls things together, like how dark matter pulls on normal matter

questions.question: What did scientists make a new map of?
What telescope did scientists use to make the map?
What does dark matter help form in the Universe?
Why can't we see dark matter directly?
options: It does not interact with light
questions.correct_answer: It does not interact with light

questions.question: What force does dark matter use to pull on normal matter?
What is dark matter compared to in the summary?

background_read: Dark matter is a mysterious substance that makes up about 27% of the Universe, but we cannot see it because it does not give off light. Scientists think it exists because of its gravity, which affects how galaxies move and form. Normal matter, like stars and planets, is what we can see and touch. The James Webb Space Telescope is a powerful tool that helps scientists study space by looking at infrared light. This study helps us understand how the Universe was built from invisible parts.
Article_Structure: WHO: Scientists from Durham University and other places
WHAT: Made a detailed map of dark matter using the James Webb Space Telescope
WHERE: Throughout the Universe, including galaxies like the Milky Way
WHY: To show how dark matter shaped the formation of stars, galaxies, and planets

perspectives.description: Scientists are excited to learn more about dark matter and how it built the Universe.
